thread.title: Would Chris Ilitch sell Detroit Tigers? He loves baseball too much
thread.title_full: Would Chris Ilitch sell Detroit Tigers? He loves baseball too much

author: freep.com
title: Would Chris Ilitch sell Detroit Tigers? He loves baseball too much
text:
MORE LAKELAND, Fla. — A couple of years ago, my son Nick was on a baseball field, on a cold and gray spring evening, fielding grounders from a coach.
I stood on a grass hill, overlooking a junior varsity baseball field.
“Do you know who is hitting the grounders to your son?” somebody asked.
He looked familiar but was too far away.
“That’s Chris Ilitch,” the person said.
“Why the heck is he here?” I asked.
“He coaches one of the younger teams.”
My son had just joined the West Oakland Wings, a travel baseball organization based in Oakland County. Ilitch’s son, Travis, played on a younger team in the organization, and Ilitch had volunteered to be an assistant coach.
Chris Ilitch stood on the field that night, working with my son, whom he didn’t even know. He dug balls out of an old bucket, hitting ball after ball while offering words of encouragement. Ilitch’s passion for baseball was obvious. Clearly, he loved what he was doing, just being on a field with a bat in his hands, working on the fundamentals.
Related:
Chris Ilitch speaks about Tigers plans: 'I love this franchise'
That memory came back on Friday afternoon, when Chris Ilitch stood in Joker Marchant Stadium, wearing a steel-blue suit and a Mr. I pin on his lapel as the Detroit Tigers honored his father, the late Mike Ilitch, before their first Grapefruit League game of spring training, a 2-0 loss against Baltimore.
It was a wonderful video tribute to a great owner, who died Feb. 10. But it also was symbolic in another way:
The Tigers are Chris Ilitch’s team now. He is the man out in front of this organization.
“I share my father’s passion for baseball … and I love this franchise,” said Ilitch, speaking publicly for the first time as Tigers owner. “Quite frankly, I love this team. I think we have a team that could win a World Series.”
It is natural to wonder what will happen to the Tigers, as the ownership of the franchise passes from father to son. It is understandable to wonder whether the Ilitch family will sell or change course.
But if somebody goes out on a JV baseball field on a cold and gray night, working with a kid who wasn’t even on his team, there is no question in my mind: This is a guy who just loves baseball.
‘No way’ Ilitch sells On Friday morning, Ilitch met with the Tigers in the clubhouse. “I told the players this morning: They are going to find the apple doesn’t fall too far from the tree,” Ilitch said.
Then, he stood behind the cage and watched the Tigers take batting practice. He brought along 12 members from the West Oakland Wings, now a group of 13-year-olds, and all the kids wore their game jerseys.
Chris Ilitch still is a volunteer assistant coach for that team.
“Here’s the one thing I can tell you,” said Brad Farquhar, the team’s head coach. “He has the worst job on our coaching staff. He’s the bullpen catcher. He readily accepts it. He has bruises on his shins to prove it.”
Yes, Chris Ilitch, the new owner of the Tigers, catches bullpens for a bunch of 13-year-olds.
Buy Photo Tigers owner Chris Ilitch talks to reporters Friday, Feb. 24, 2017 at Publix Field at Joker Marchant Stadium in Lakeland, Fla. (Photo: Kirthmon F. Dozier, DFP)
The West Oakland Wings typically play between 50 and 60 games a year and they have traveled all over the country, going from Georgia to Kentucky to New York. “I don’t think he has missed a game, ever, not one,” Farquhar said. “Maybe a practice but not a game. He wants to be around his son, he wants to be around baseball.”
Last summer, when the West Oakland Wings played at a week-long tournament at Cooperstown Dreams Park in upstate New York, Chris Ilitch was assigned an inglorious task. “It was his job to get the ice,” Farquhar said. “He was schlepping ice bags down. Now, he was smart enough to get a wagon.”
He spent a week sleeping in bunk beds in a cabin with no air conditioning, with a bunch of 12-year-olds, just like all the other coaches do at the Cooperstown tournament.
Related:
Detroit Tigers would fetch princely sum if Ilitch heirs sell
“He is down to earth and as real as you can get,” Farquhar said. “The kids call him Coach Ilitch. We call him Chris. His son Travis is a joy to have. Looks you in the eye. Shakes your hand. Works hard. I get on him like any kid.”
This winter, the West Oakland Wings had a team bonding night at Farquhar’s house. “It was a sleepover," Farquhar said. “There he was, in a sleeping bag.”
While some fans wonder whether the Ilitch family will sell the team, now that Mike has died, Farquhar has spent countless hours with Chris Ilitch, at probably a couple hundred travel baseball games, and he is convinced that won’t happen.
“No way,” Farquhar said. “No way. He loves baseball. He appreciates what his dad built.”
Remembering Mike Ilitch Mitch Albom: Mike Ilitch loved his teams as much as we do Mike Ilitch’s complex relationship with Detroit Ilitch leaves music, entertainment legacy in downtown Detroit Would Mike Ilitch's story be possible today? Did you know? Mike Ilitch once paid Rosa Parks' rent Jim Leyland 'brokenhearted' Tigers couldn't win title for Mike Ilitch Mike Ilitch was a great owner, a man of vision Tigers, Red Wings owner and pizza titan Mike Ilitch dead at 87 How legendary owner Mike Ilitch made Detroit 'Hockeytown' How baseball and the Detroit Tigers became Mike Ilitch's true love Mike Ilitch funeral: Private service, public tribute to follow Mike Ilitch legacy wall: Share your memories and condolences Chris Ilitch now in charge of dad's empire under succession plan Sounds of Mr. I You can learn a lot about a man by how he treats his kids, as well as his children’s friends.
And on Friday afternoon, as the Tigers honored Mike Ilitch, a group of baseball players from Oakland County sat in the first two rows in Joker Marchant. It was the West Oakland Wings. Travis Ilitch sat in the middle of the team, taking his hat off during a moment of silence for his grandfather.
It was a touching, classy celebration with a video tribute played on the new video screen in left field, part of the $48-million renovation of this stadium. “Physical environment is a big part of creating a culture,” Ilitch said, sounding a lot like his father, and certainly following the example set by his father. “We are a world-class organization and that is what we want to remain. This is a big part of it.”
During the ceremony, Chris Ilitch stood on the grass, as Victor Martinez, Ian Kinsler, Francisco Rodriguez and Justin Upton revealed a Mr. I insignia painted along the first-base line. It seemed so fitting, to have some of the biggest stars take part in the celebration. Mr. I always loved stars. He understood how the fans come to watch the stars play.

You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 18 2 of 18 3 of 18 4 of 18 5 of 18 6 of 18 7 of 18 8 of 18 9 of 18 10 of 18 11 of 18 12 of 18 13 of 18 14 of 18 15 of 18 16 of 18 17 of 18 18 of 18 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Beyond the outfield wall, Tigers manager Brad Ausmus held the American flag so it wouldn’t hit the ground.
General manger Al Avila held a Mr. I flag, as Justin Verlander and Miguel Cabrera hoisted it up the flag pole.
“I thought it was very nice, well done,” Ausmus said.
After the ceremony was done, Chris Ilitch stood along the first-base line, shaking hands with the players, looking so comfortable to be on the field.
“He was very good when speaking to the team,” Ausmus said. “With Mr. I’s passing, he’s the guy now.”
Buy Photo From left: The Tigers' Justin Upton, Ian Kinsler, Francisco Rodriguez , Victor Martinez and Chris Ilitch stand by the "Mr. I" logo in honor of owner Mike Ilitch, who died Feb. 10, before action against Baltimore on Friday, Feb. 24, 2017 at Publix Field at Joker Marchant Stadium in Lakeland, Fla. (Photo: Kirthmon F. Dozier, DFP)
Chris Ilitch said there is no mandate to cut the payroll but that remains to be seen. He talked about the importance of finding talent and developing players, which takes on a different meaning when you consider how he spends his summer. Developing talent? Learning to field a grounder? A youth baseball coach understands that better than anybody, especially after he has hit countless ground balls to kids and has caught countless pitches in the bullpen.
Will that make him a good owner? Not necessarily. But it's a great place to start.
It seems clear: Chris Ilitch isn’t going anywhere. He loves baseball too much.
Contact Jeff Seidel: jseidel@freepress.com. Follow him on Twitter @seideljeff . To read his recent columns, go to freep.com/sports/jeff-seidel .
